newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Foreign banks seek stakes in Viet Hoa - paper.
newsitem.headline: Foreign banks seek stakes in Viet Hoa - paper.

text.p: Germany's Bank Kreiss AG and two Taiwanese banks are negotiating to buy 30 percent of Vietnam's Viet Hoa when the troubled private bank raises fresh capital, the Saigon Times Daily said on Thursday.
"German Kreiss Bank and two Taiwanese banks are negotiating with Viet Hoa to buy 33 billion dong ($2.83 million) worth of shares," the paper said, without naming the Taiwanese banks.
An official at Bank Kreiss's representative office in Ho Chi Minh City, who declined to be identified, confirmed that the German bank may buy shares in Viet Hoa.
"We are in the process of discussion," the official said. "It's not completed yet."
Industry sources say that the sudden death of the Ho Chi Minh City-based bank's charismatic chairman, Tran Tan Tai, in early February triggered a run on deposits at Viet Hoa.

Foreign bankers believe that the bank, which is majority owned by ethnic Chinese in the city's Cholon district, was just one of several privately held banks which have run into liquidity problems in recent months.
The Saigon Times Daily said the bank's shareholders agreed at an extraordinary meeting last week to increase Viet Hoa's registered capital to 110 billion dong.
The central State Bank of Vietnam said the bank's current registered capital was 70 billion dong.
